title: Codecov configuration file
description: The Codecov configuration file is used to configure your repository's Codecov experience.

url.title: Url
url.description: A url you want to send notifications too. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/notifications#standard-notification-fields

token.title: Token
token.description: The repository upload token. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecov-uploader#upload-token

slug.title: Slug
slug.description: Self Hosted only - specify a slug manually

bot.title: Bot
bot.description: The username you want to use for Codecov operations. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/team-bot

branch.title: Branch
branch.description: Specify a branch manually in your yaml

ci.title: Ci
ci.description: Additional CI provider URLs you want Codecov to recognize. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/detecting-ci-services

strict_yaml_branch.title: Strict yaml branch
strict_yaml_branch.description: Specify a branch you want Codecov to always only read the YAML from. More info: https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-yaml#section-restricting-changes

max_report_age.title: Max report age
max_report_age.description: The age you want coverage reports to expire at, or if you want to disable this check. Expired reports will not be processed by codecov. More info: https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-yaml#section-expired-reports

disable_default_path_fixes.title: Disable default path fixes
disable_default_path_fixes.description: Should Codecov's default path fixes be disabled. More info: https://docs.codecov.io/docs/fixing-paths. Enum: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

require_ci_to_pass.title: Require ci to pass
require_ci_to_pass.description: Should Codecov wait for all other statuses to pass before sending its status. Enum: True, False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

allow_coverage_offsets.title: Allow coverage offsets
allow_coverage_offsets.description: Codecov will calculate a coverage diff based on last coverage found and the diff to the base commit. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/comparing-commits#comparing-pull-request-base-reports. Enum: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

allow_pseudo_compare.title: Allow pseudo compare
allow_pseudo_compare.description: Allow Codecov to find an alternative base if base of comparison has no coverage. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/comparing-commits#comparing-pull-request-base-reports. Enum: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

uploads.title: Uploads
uploads.description: Diasble Codecov cloud report archiving. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/v4.6/docs/codecovyml-reference#codecov-cloud-report-archiving. Enum: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

after_n_builds.title: After n builds
after_n_builds.description: How many uploaded reports Codecov should wait to receive before sending statuses. More info: https://docs.codecov.io/docs/notifications#section-preventing-notifications-until-after-n-builds.

wait_for_ci.title: Wait for ci
wait_for_ci.description: Wait for CI to finish to send notifictionas. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#codecovnotifywait_for_ci. Enum: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

require_ci_to_pass.title: Require ci to pass
require_ci_to_pass.description: Wait for all CI statuses to pass. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#codecovrequire_ci_to_pass. Enum: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off

notify.title: Notify
notify.description: Configure how Codecov sends a PR comment

codecov.title: Codecov
codecov.description: Configure general codecov settings. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecov-yaml

precision.title: Precision
precision.description: What precision do you want the coverage value to be. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#coverageprecision

round.title: Round
round.description: Configure how you want Codecov to round your coverage numbers. Enum: down,  up,  nearest

range.title: Range
range.description: Configure how you want Codecov to color your coverage. Coverage below the first number will be red, coverage between each number yellow, and coverage above the second number will be green. Format: xx...yy

slack.title: Slack
slack.description: This is the path for Slack notifications to fire. Below "slack:" start your configuration with an indented "default:". Available keys after "default:" are URL, Threshold, Only_pulls, Branches, Flags and Paths. [Slack notification docs](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/notifications#slack)

attachments.title: Attachments
attachments.description: These are attachments you can make as strings to the Slack notifier with the pattern: ^([^,]+)(,[^,]+)*$

url.title: Url
url.description: Used to store the Slack hooks URL associated with your Slack notifier: https://hooks.slack.com/services/abc/123

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: Used to store the branch(es) that will report code coverage. Defaults to all branches. Each new branch is a new indented line

threshold.title: Threshold
threshold.description: The coverage threshold on which you would like to send a notification. If the coverage changes by more than the amount in the threshold field, a notification will be sent, otherwise it will not. Default to `None`, which means that notifications will always be sent regardless of coverage change amount.

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: Specify the flags for which you would like notifications to be sent. Defaults to all flags. [Read more about flags](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/flags). Add a new, indented line for each flag. Regular experessions are permitted with the pattern: ^[\w\.\-]{1,45}$

base.title: Base
base.description: The base commit type to which you would like to send notifications. Options are 'parent','pr', and 'auto'. parent: compare the commit being notified on to its direct parent. 'pr': compare the commit being notified on to the base of a PR if the commit is in a PR. 'auto': automatically choose the appropriate comparison. If the commit being notified on is in a PR, pr will be used, otherwise parent will be used. This is the default.

only_pulls.title: Only pulls
only_pulls.description: True / False binary to specify if you only want notifications to fire on pull requests (vs. individual commits on the branch). Default is `false`, which will notify on all new commits.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Only send a notification if the specified file paths change. Augments the flags setting. Add a new, indented line for each path. If both flags and paths are specified, a notification will be triggered if files covered by the supplied flags OR paths change.

gitter.title: Gitter
gitter.description: This is the root for Gitter notifications to fire. Below "gitter:" start your configuration with an indented "default:". Available keys after "default:" are URL, Threshold, Only_pulls, Branches, Flags and Paths. [Gitter notification docs](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/notifications#gitter)

url.title: Url
url.description: Used to store the Gitter hooks URL associated with your Gitter notifier: "https://webhooks.gitter.im/e/9d1957r0a481787c756z"

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: Used to store the branch(es) that will report code coverage. Defaults to all branches. Each new branch is a new indented line

threshold.title: Threshold
threshold.description: The coverage threshold on which you would like to send a notification. If the coverage changes by more than the amount in the threshold field, a notification will be sent, otherwise it will not. Default to `None`, which means that notifications will always be sent regardless of coverage change amount.

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: Specify the flags for which you would like notifications to be sent. Defaults to all flags. [Read more about flags](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/flags). Add a new, indented line for each flag. Regular experessions are permitted with the pattern: ^[\w\.\-]{1,45}$

base.title: Base
base.description: The base commit type to which you would like to send notifications. Options are 'parent','pr', and 'auto'. parent: compare the commit being notified on to its direct parent. 'pr': compare the commit being notified on to the base of a PR if the commit is in a PR. 'auto': automatically choose the appropriate comparison. If the commit being notified on is in a PR, pr will be used, otherwise parent will be used. This is the default.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Only send a notification if the specified file paths change. Augments the flags setting. Add a new, indented line for each path. If both flags and paths are specified, a notification will be triggered if files covered by the supplied flags OR paths change.

webhook.title: Webhook
webhook.description: This is the root for making a webhook for notifications outside of Slack or Gitter. Below "webhook:" start your configuration with an indented "default:". Available keys after "default:" are URL, Threshold, Only_pulls, Branches, Flags and Paths. [General notification docs](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/notifications#standard-notification-fields)

url.title: Url
url.description: Used to store the generalized webhook URL associated with your notifier

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: Used to store the branch(es) that will report code coverage. Defaults to all branches. Each new branch is a new indented line

threshold.title: Threshold
threshold.description: The coverage threshold on which you would like to send a notification. If the coverage changes by more than the amount in the threshold field, a notification will be sent, otherwise it will not. Default to `None`, which means that notifications will always be sent regardless of coverage change amount.

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: Specify the flags for which you would like notifications to be sent. Defaults to all flags. [Read more about flags](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/flags). Add a new, indented line for each flag. Regular expressions are permitted with the pattern: ^[\w\.\-]{1,45}$

base.title: Base
base.description: The base commit type to which you would like to send notifications. Options are 'parent','pr', and 'auto'. parent: compare the commit being notified on to its direct parent. 'pr': compare the commit being notified on to the base of a PR if the commit is in a PR. 'auto': automatically choose the appropriate comparison. If the commit being notified on is in a PR, pr will be used, otherwise parent will be used. This is the default.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Only send a notification if the specified file paths change. Augments the flags setting. Add a new, indented line for each path. If both flags and paths are specified, a notification will be triggered if files covered by the supplied flags OR paths change.

notify.title: Notify
notify.description: A collection of notification tools for sending coverage data to services outside of Git. Out of the box tools are Slack and Gitter, or you can make your own wehbook. Available keys are slack, gitter, webhook, and after_n_builds. [Read about Codecov notifications here](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/notifications).

flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.title: Flag coverage not uploaded behavior
flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.description: Determines how we handle status checks for which no flag coverage has been newly uploaded on a commit. This includes status checks where flags have carriedforward coverage (since coverage was no newly uploaded), as well as flags for which coverage is missing entirely. This is useful if, for example, you're working on a project in a monorepo and don't want to see status checks related to other projects. Note that this only applies to status checks that specify flags. If there are no flags on a check, the status check will be processed as usual.  Options are a.) include: (default) All the status checks defined in the YAML file will be processed and sent as normal b.) exclude: Status checks that haven't newly uploaded any flag coverage will not be sent c.) pass: Status checks that haven't newly uploaded any flag coverage will be passed automatically.

carryforward_behavior.title: Carryforward behavior
carryforward_behavior.description: Determines how we handle status checks for which flags that were carried forward. This is useful if, for example, you're working on a project in a monorepo and don't want to see status checks related to other projects. Note that this only applies to status checks that specify flags. If there are no flags on a check, the status check will be processed as usual.  Options are a.) include: (default) All the status checks defined in the YAML file will be processed and sent as normal b.) exclude: Status checks that carried forward coverage will not be included c.) pass: Status checks that have carried forward coverage will pass automatically.

default_rules.title: Default rules
default_rules.description: A path of the `status` configuration that provides advanced configuration for repos not uploading all of their coverage on every commit. Keys available are `flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior` and `carryforward_behavior`.

project.title: Project
project.description: Contains the configuration for a given project status check. Setting to False will disable the project status check.

target.title: Target
target.description: Set the project status check to a number (80), percent (80%) or `auto`. This specifies the minimum coverage number accepted by this project status check. Setting to `auto` will compare coverage against the BASE commit.

threshold.title: Threshold
threshold.description: Allow coverage to drop by x% below the target and still pass the status check.

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: A list of user defined Flags to use for the status check. The combined coverage from those flags will be reported.

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: A list of the branches that, when used, will trigger this status.

if_ci_failed.title: If ci failed
if_ci_failed.description: Options are `error` (default) and `success`. `error` will set the Codecov status to success only if the CI is also successful. `success` will set the Codecov status to success even if CI fails

if_not_found.title: If not found
if_not_found.description: Options are `success` (default) and `failure`. `success` will pass if there is no report for the HEAD commit. Use this on commits/PRs where you won't be uploading coverage but still want Codecov status checks to pass. `error` will fail if there is no report for the HEAD commit.

measurement.title: Measurement
measurement.description: Specify the type of coverage measurement. Options are `line`, `statement`, `branch`, `method`, `complexity`

removed_code_behavior.title: Removed code behavior
removed_code_behavior.description: Specify the behavior if coverage drops due to code removal. Options are `removals_only`, `adjust_base`, `fully_covered_patch`, `off`, and `False`. See https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#removed_code_behavior for more details.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Similar to `flags`, a list of paths and/or regular expressions to use for the status check. The combined coverage from files that match will be reported.

flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.title: Flag coverage not uploaded behavior
flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.description: Determines how to handle status checks for which no flag coverage (including carryforward flags) has been newly uploaded on a commit. Options are: `include`: (default) All the status checks defined in the YAML file will be processed and sent as normal. `exclude`: Status checks that haven't newly uploaded any flag coverage will not be sent. `pass`: Status checks that haven't newly uploaded any flag coverage will be passed automatically. For information see https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior

patch.title: Patch
patch.description: Contains the configuration for a given patch status check. Setting to False will disable the patch status check.

target.title: Target
target.description: Set the patch status check to a number (80), percent (80%) or `auto`. This specifies the minimum coverage number accepted by this patch status check. Setting to `auto` will compare coverage against the BASE commit.

threshold.title: Threshold
threshold.description: Allow coverage to drop by x% below the target and still pass the status check.

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: A list of user defined Flags to use for the status check. The combined coverage from those flags will be reported.

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: A list of the branches that, when used, will trigger this status.

if_ci_failed.title: If ci failed
if_ci_failed.description: Options are `error` (default) and `success`. `error` will set the Codecov status to success only if the CI is also successful. `success` will set the Codecov status to success even if CI fails

if_not_found.title: If not found
if_not_found.description: Options are `success` (default) and `failure`. `success` will pass if there is no report for the HEAD commit. Use this on commits/PRs where you won't be uploading coverage but still want Codecov status checks to pass. `error` will fail if there is no report for the HEAD commit.

measurement.title: Measurement
measurement.description: Specify the type of coverage measurement. Options are `line`, `statement`, `branch`, `method`, `complexity`

removed_code_behavior.title: Removed code behavior
removed_code_behavior.description: Specify the behavior if coverage drops due to code removal. Options are `removals_only`, `adjust_base`, `fully_covered_patch`, `off`, and `False`. See https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#removed_code_behavior for more details.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Similar to `flags`, a list of paths and/or regular expressions to use for the status check. The combined coverage from files that match will be reported.

flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.title: Flag coverage not uploaded behavior
flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.description: Determines how to handle status checks for which no flag coverage (including carryforward flags) has been newly uploaded on a commit. Options are: `include`: (default) All the status checks defined in the YAML file will be processed and sent as normal. `exclude`: Status checks that haven't newly uploaded any flag coverage will not be sent. `pass`: Status checks that haven't newly uploaded any flag coverage will be passed automatically. For information see https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior

changes.title: Changes
changes.description: Codecov will detect changes in coverage that are NOT included in the commit/pull diff, and report these changes as a commit status. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#changes-status

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: A list of user defined Flags to use for the changes check. The combined coverage from those flags will be reported. Flag names must match pattern: ^[\w\.\-]{1,45}$

base.title: Base
base.description: [Deprecated] Base picking approach to use for changes statues. Options: parent, pr, auto. It is recommended to use Codecov CLI's base picking feature instead: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/cli-options#pr-base-picking

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: The branches for which the changes status will be active. Nullable.

if_ci_failed.title: If ci failed
if_ci_failed.description: The status to send if CI fails. Options include: success, failure. On error Codecov will on set a passing status if CI passes, on succes Codecov will set the status to success even if CI fails.

if_not_found.title: If not found
if_not_found.description: The status to send if there is no report for the head. Options: failure, success. failure: the status will fail if there is no report for the head. success: the status will pass if there is no report for the head. Use this on commits / PRs where you won't be uploading coverage but still want codecov status checks to pass.

removed_code_behavior.title: Removed code behavior
removed_code_behavior.description: These behaviors allows users to specify what should happen to the project status in case changes causes overall coverage to drop, but are part of good development practices. Options include: removals_only, adjust_base, fully_covered_patch, off, False. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#removed_code_behavior

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Paths to consider when determining the status result. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#paths

flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.title: Flag coverage not uploaded behavior
flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior.description: Determines how we handle status checks for which no flag coverage has been newly uploaded on a commit. Options: include,  exclude,  pass. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status#flag_coverage_not_uploaded_behavior

status.title: Status
status.description: Configuration for various status checks supported in Codecov. Useful for blocking Pull Requests that don't meet a particular coverage threshold. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/commit-status

coverage.title: Coverage
coverage.description: Configuration options that determine how Codecov calulates and reports on code coverage metrics.

partials_as_hits.title: Partials as hits
partials_as_hits.description: Count partial coverage as hits for the Golang language. Useful to enable if Codecov is reporting lower coverage than your local reporting tool. Options: True, False, yes, no, on, off

go.title: Go
go.description: Configruation options for Codecov's Golang coverage parser.

enable_partials.title: Enable partials
enable_partials.description: Count partial coverage as hits for the JavaScript language. Useful to enable if Codecov is reporting lower coverage than your local reporting tool. Options: True, False, yes, no, on, off

javascript.title: Javascript
javascript.description: Configruation options for Codecov's JavaScript coverage parser.

conditional.title: Conditional
conditional.description: Count conditional coverage lines toward the coverage total when using gcov. Options include: True, False, yes, no, on, off

loop.title: Loop
loop.description: Count loop coverage lines toward the coverage total when using gcov. Options include: True, False, yes, no, on, off

method.title: Method
method.description: Count method coverage lines toward the coverage total when using gcov. Options include: True, False, yes, no, on, off

macro.title: Macro
macro.description: Count macro coverage lines toward the coverage total when using gcov. Options include: True, False, yes, no, on, off

branch_detection.title: Branch detection
branch_detection.description: Controls how Codecov parses branch coverage in gcov reports. The coverage must exist in the uploaded report for us to parse it. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#parsersgcov

gcov.title: Gcov
gcov.description: Configuration options for the gcov coverage parser. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#parsersgcov

partials_as_hits.title: Partials as hits
partials_as_hits.description: Count partial coverage as hits for Jacoco coverage reports. Useful to enable if Codecov is reporting lower coverage than your local reporting tool. Options: True, False, yes, no, on, off

jacoco.title: Jacoco
jacoco.description: Configuration options for the gcov coverage parser. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#parsersjacoco

parsers.title: Parsers
parsers.description: Configuration settings for Codecov various language specific test coverage parsers. More info: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecovyml-reference#parsers

ignore.title: Ignore
ignore.description: File paths for Codecov to ignore when processing coverage reports. More information: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/ignoring-paths

fixes.title: Fixes
fixes.description: A list of path fixes that Codecov applies to uploaded coverage reports. Before using path fixing, reading the docs is greatly encouraged: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/fixing-paths

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: A list of flags Codecov will apply in order to segment code coverage. Rules for flag names: min length: 1, max length: 45, pattern: ^[\w\.\-]+$. Before using flags, reading the docs is greatly encouraged: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/flags

carryforward_mode.title: Carryforward mode
carryforward_mode.description: Specified whether a flag should carry its coverage forward to future commits. Carryforward flags is an advanced feature, and reading the documentation is recommended: https://docs.codecov.com/docs/flags#carryforward-flags

ignore.title: Ignore
ignore.description: Ignore coverage for specific lines of code. You can provide a comma-separated list of line ranges or individual line numbers to be ignored.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Are used to define the paths to your project's source files or directories for which you want to generate code coverage reports.

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: Customize how branches are treated in the code coverage analysis.

after_n_builds.title: After n builds
after_n_builds.description: Value rules after N builds refer to coverage requirements or thresholds that are applied after a certain number of builds or iterations.

statuses.title: Statuses
statuses.description: Flag management rule statuses refer to the different states or conditions associated with flag management rules.

carryforward_mode.title: Carryforward mode
carryforward_mode.description: Reference of past coverage for tests that are not run on current commit.

carryforward.title: Carryforward
carryforward.description: Carryforward Flags are designed for projects that do not upload total coverage for every commit. Users can define the following states for flags: True,  False,  yes,  no,  on,  off.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Define rules that specify conditions and actions for flag management. These rules can be based on various criteria such as coverage thresholds, branch names, commit messages, or other factors relevant to your project.

ignore.title: Ignore
ignore.description: To ignore or exclude specific files, directories, or patterns from flag management actions, you can define a flag management rule with conditions that exclude those specific elements.

after_n_builds.title: After n builds
after_n_builds.description: Refers to the ability to apply specific flag management rules after a certain number of builds or iterations. Gradually enforce stricter or different flag management behavior as your project progresses over time.

default_rules.title: Default rules
default_rules.description: Rules are a set of defined conditions and actions that control the behavior of flags during the code coverage analysis process.

individual_flags.title: Individual flags
individual_flags.description: Individual flags refer to specific configuration options or settings that can be used to customize the behavior of the code coverage reporting and analysis process.

flag_management.title: Flag management
flag_management.description: Allows you to control the behavior of flags during the code coverage analysis process.

statuses.title: Statuses
statuses.description: Component management rule statuses refer to the different states or conditions associated with component management rules.

flag_regexes.title: Flag regexes
flag_regexes.description: Refers to the use of regular expressions to define patterns for matching specific flags or conditions during the code coverage analysis process.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Define rules that specify conditions and actions for component management. These rules can be based on various criteria such as coverage thresholds, branch names, commit messages, or other factors relevant to your project.

default_rules.title: Default rules
default_rules.description: Rules are a set of defined conditions and actions that control the behavior of components during the code coverage analysis process.

individual_components.title: Individual components
individual_components.description: Individual components refer to specific configuration options or settings that can be used to customize the behavior of the code coverage reporting and analysis process.

component_management.title: Component management
component_management.description: Use components you specify to create custom statuses and get coverage information from parts of your code that are not easily broken up into different uploads or span multiple flag groups.

layout.title: Layout
layout.description: Comment layout refers to the structure and formatting of the comments generated during the code coverage analysis process. The layout of comments can vary depending on the specific features and configurations of, as well as the platform or integration being used.

require_changes.title: Require changes
require_changes.description: If you need to indicate in your comments that certain code requires changes or modifications, you can use specific keywords or phrases to convey this information. You can tailor the comments to suit your specific needs by using keywords like 'TODO,' 'FIXME,' or 'CHANGES NEEDED' to explicitly communicate that certain code sections need attention.

require_base.title: Require base
require_base.description: To indicate that a certain code section requires a base or starting point for coverage analysis add the phrase 'Base required' or any other relevant keyword, you clearly communicate that a starting point or base coverage is necessary to accurately assess the coverage of those specific code sections.

require_head.title: Require head
require_head.description: If you want to add comments to indicate that a certain code section requires a 'head' or an updated state for coverage analysis, you can add the phrase 'Head required' or any other relevant keyword, you clearly communicate that an updated or current state of the code is needed to accurately assess the coverage of those specific code sections.

show_critical_paths.title: Show critical paths
show_critical_paths.description: When adding comments to highlight the critical path of your code, you can include the phrase 'Critical Path' or any other relevant keyword, you explicitly communicate the essential steps in the code execution flow.

branches.title: Branches
branches.description: Comment branches refer to the specific branches or conditions under which comments are generated during the code coverage analysis. These comments provide feedback, suggestions, or information related to code coverage for specific branches of your codebase.

paths.title: Paths
paths.description: Comment paths refer to the specific locations within your codebase where comments are added to provide feedback or information related to code coverage analysis. Comment paths can be associated with individual lines of code, code sections, or specific files.

flags.title: Flags
flags.description: Comment flags refer to special markers or indicators that can be added to comments in your code to control the behavior of Codecov's code coverage analysis.

behavior.title: Behavior
behavior.description: When adding comments to describe the behavior of your code for coverage analysis, use the phrase 'Behavior' or any other relevant keyword, you make it clear that these comments describe the expected behavior of the code.

after_n_builds.title: After n builds
after_n_builds.description: If you want to add comments that appear after a specific number of builds or iterations for coverage analysis, you can include the phrase 'After n builds' or any other relevant keyword, you communicate that these comments should be taken into account after a specific number of builds or iterations.

show_carryforward_flags.title: Show carryforward flags
show_carryforward_flags.description: If you want to add comments to indicate the presence of carry-forward flags in your code for coverage analysis, you can use the phrase 'Carry-forward Flag' or any other relevant keyword, you clearly communicate the presence of carry-forward flags and their significance for coverage analysis.

hide_comment_details.title: Hide comment details
hide_comment_details.description: If you want to add comments but hide the specific details or implementation information within the comments for coverage analysis, you can use abstract or generic descriptions to hide the specific details of the code implementation within the comments while still conveying the coverage significance of different sections.

comment.title: Comment
comment.description: Refer to the feedback or remarks that Codecov can provide on your code coverage results. These comments are typically added to pull requests or specific lines of code to provide additional information or suggestions regarding the code coverage analysis.

annotations.title: Annotations
annotations.description: Checks enable users to see inline code annotations for contributed code on a PR that was not covered by tests, making it much easier for developers to see uncovered code contributions without leaving the GitHub PR.

github_checks.title: Github checks
github_checks.description: Display code coverage information and analysis results directly within the GitHub interface.

fixes.title: Fixes
fixes.description: Add path fixes to your codecov.yml configuration to see critical changes.

grouping_attributes.title: Grouping attributes
grouping_attributes.description: Grouping attributes allow you to categorize your code coverage data based on specific criteria. These attributes can be applied to files, directories, or other relevant components of your codebase. Grouping attributes provide a way to aggregate and filter coverage information, enabling you to gain insights into different aspects of your codebase's test coverage.

critical_files_paths.title: Critical files paths
critical_files_paths.description: You can supply any of the following as an element of critical_files_paths: 1.The fully qualified path to the file relative to the root of the repository, 2. A path containing globs. 3. A regular expression.

profiling.title: Profiling
profiling.description: Impact Analysis requires a profiling token used to identify your repository and authenticate API requests. You can find your token in your repo settings page.

beta_groups.title: Beta groups
beta_groups.description: To see Impacted Entrypoints in your pull request comments, 'betaprofiling' must be added to the comment.layout section of your codecov.yml.
